repnme.cdata!:
Argentina - Mining Sector Development
            Technical Assistance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the project is rated
            satisfactory, sustainability likely, and the institutional
            development impact is substantial. Several lessons are drawn
            from the project. The major lesson is that by creating an
            enabling environment, and responsive institutions to
            interface with the private sector, investments derived
            significant contributions in terms of mining exploration,
            and job opportunities. Yet another positive example points
            at the importance to approach sector reform in an integrated
            way, for example as it concerns the development of mining
            rights, and environmental management capacity, instead of in
            a piecemeal manner. Once again, lessons reemphasize the
            importance of Government commitment, which was politically
            supportive both at the federal, and provincial levels. And,
            it is worth noting the strong sector work prior to
            preparation, which effectively paved the way for reforms,
            allowing sufficient time for a thorough project design, and
            a well-defined coordination between the federal, and
            provincial implementing units. Likewise, the strategy
            adopted to implement the institutional capacity building,
            was particularly successful, based on the institutional
            mandate, designed with the participation of most
            stakeholders, that included a participatory diagnostic,
            responsive to provincial specificities.

repnme.cdata!:
Argentina - Mining Development Technical
            Assistance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The main objective of the Mining
            Development Technical Assistance Project is to develop,
            through an institutional development technical assistance
            operation, the govenment's policy, regulatory and
            institutional reforms which encourage the expansion of
            private investment in mining in an environmentally sound
            way. The project has four components: 1) a policy
            development component to ensure the consistency of mining
            sector policy with the country's overall economic
            liberalization efforts; to revise and prepare the legal
            framework; and to develop tools for its implementation,
            including procedures for the provincial administration of
            mining rights and appropriate environmental norms and
            standards; 2) a policy implementation component to help
            develop the capacity of the federal Mining Secretariat and
            sector agencies in selected provinces including their
            cadastral and registry systems and advisory services, as
            well as the mechanisms to monitor and enforce environmental
            management. It will also finance relevant skills transfer,
            training and divestiture efforts; 3) a support services
            component to build up the geological and thematic mapping; a
            sector data bank and public information network; mineral and
            market statistics and promotion facilities; a geological
            repository and ancillary facilities; and the selective
            strengthening of the mineral and geological laboratory
            system; and 4) a project coordinating unit to oversee
            project implementation.
